Award.AwardTitle: How do migrating epithelia change direction?
Award.AbstractNarration:
LAY ABSTRACT:
Animals build and maintain functional organs throughout their lives. To build an organ, multiple steps occur as the embryo develops, both to make all the different types of cells needed for that organ, and to organize these different cells so that they can work together to perform the organ's function. A common strategy for organizing cells is through coordinated cellular movements and shape changes. This project aims to understand how each different kind of cell obtains the information it needs to move into the correct places and acquire the needed shape. This process requires that cells recognize each other, assess their current location in the developing tissue, and finally, use information from their environment and/or in their DNA blueprint to navigate through the tissue to the location where they are needed. To understand how cells manage this intricate dance, the investigator will study an example where cells organize to create an organlike structure that develops into a fruit fly egg. A series of precise cellular movements is needed to build the eggshell, which protects the developing embryo. Fly ovaries will be cultured and cell movements will be imaged through the microscope, using genetic and antibody assays to identify the specific proteins that cells use to interact with each other. These studies will be able to distinguish whether the major source of information for a cell's movements come from an internal program or from external environmental cues. The proteins and mechanisms identified will expand the knowledge of the cellular repertoire available to create organized structure in the many different types of organs observed across animal phyla. This research will provide essential scientific training for undergraduate and graduate students at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas. They will acquire important skills in teamwork, critical thinking, data management,as well as the needed skills to perform laboratory research.

TECHNICAL ABSTRACT:
The experiments of this proposal will examine the mechanisms by which a migrating sheet of cells can change its direction of migration. The work will focus on oogenesis of the fruit fly Drosophila melanogaster, to take advantage of sophisticated tools for genetic manipulations and new technologies for real-time, time-lapse imaging of cellular movements in ovary explants. Based on previous research, two models for the mechanisms that induce the change in direction will be contrasted; these models are not mutually exclusive. One model is that each cell decides independently to change its direction, through an intrinsic program of regulated gene expression in response to a bone morphogenetic protein (BMP) morphogen gradient. Experiments will test specific candidate transcriptional regulators for their requirements in the onset of specific phases of the new migration. The second model is that the cells respond to an extrinsic signal that reorients their direction or otherwise changes their migration behavior. This aspect of the project follows up on published reports that the BMP response system may use non-transcriptional mechanisms to induce changes in cell shape, as well as preliminary data that another signaling system is modulated in these cells. The investigator predicts that intrinsic gene regulation initiates the competence for a migration response, and that extrinsic signals orient the cells' migratory behaviors. This work will identify the molecular links between developmental gene regulatory networks and the cellular effectors that create the diverse array of functional architecture seen in tissues of multicellular organisms. In addition to these research activities, the investigator is collaboratively organizing a monthly Science Cafe (www.sciencecafes.org) to provide an interactive venue for local and regional scientists to discuss current scientific topics with the general Las Vegas community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The organs of the body are lined by epithelia, tightly linked cell layers that enclose the tissue and separate it from surrounding tissues or the environment. Cells within an epithelium maintain cell junctions that create barriers between the organ and its surrounding environment; these junctions are maintained as the epithelium reorganizes with the changing shape and size of the tissue. Our lab uses the model organism Drosophila melanogaster to study the mechanisms used by epithelial cells to maintain their linked organization, while they change shape and reorganize with the underlying cells of the organ or tissue. Specifically, we have studied the follicular epithelium that lines a developing fly egg follicle, or egg chamber.

 

The follicle cells that make up the follicular epithelium interact with the underlying germ cells that will make the ultimate egg of the fly. The epithelium expands with the growing egg and reorganizes to create the shape of the eggshell, which forms from proteins and lipids that the follicle cells secreted over the egg. Under this award, we focused on a specific migration by the follicle cells called centripetal migration. Centripetal migration occurs shortly after the epithelium stops its overall migration around the surface of the germ cell clusters. A specific ring of follicle cells changes the direction of their movement to migrate into the germ cell cluster to spread over the anterior end of the oocyte, separating it from its sister germ cells. The rest of the epithelium remains on the surface, spreading to maintain the closed environment of the egg chamber.

 

First, we defined the sequence and duration of cell shape changes and movements used by the centripetally migrating follicle cells as they move into the germ cell cluster, separating the oocyte from its sister cells. This timeline then was used to identify specific cell biological steps that are disrupted when a required gene product is unavailable. We evaluated the specific step of centripetal migration that is disrupted when the adhesion protein, E-Cadherin is missing, specifically comparing the contribution from E-cadherin in the follicle cells that are migrating, versus E-cadherin on the underlying oocyte. This study indicated that E-Cadherin adhesion between follicle cells is important both for follicle cell-follicle cell traction as the first few cells extend into the germ cell cluster, and also to anchor the cells that have not begun to migrate. Continuing work will identify the specific cell biological step that is regulated by BMP signaling. This signal also is required for the first few cells to complete their inward movement to cover the anterior oocyte, but at a slightly later step than E-cadherin.  

 

A parallel project focused on the integration of BMP signaling with the activity of intracellular NDR kinase signaling pathways, which control cell shape and epithelial organization, along with proliferation and overall tissue size. This work focused on the Mobs, which are small proteins that facilitate activation of NDR kinases. Prior data from our lab suggested that BMP signaling drives expression of Mob2 in the centripetally migrating cells. Drosophila has four Mobs, two of which were previously shown to interact with NDR kinases. We found that Mob2 and the Tricornered NDR kinase are required for specific steps in formation of follicular epithelial extensions called the dorsal appendages, but do not appear to be essential for centripetal migration. Intriguingly, the requirement for Tricornered NDR kinase impacts the formation of dorsal appendage tubes at an early step in tube formation, whereas Mob2 is required only for the full extension of the tube into an elongated dorsal appendage. Continuing work is examining whether a different Mob acts earlier in tube formation, or whether this function of Tricornered is Mob independent. The linkage of BMP signaling with Tricornered activity remains to be evaluated; understanding how Mob proteins may be regulated to redirect NDR kinase activity remains an important question. Altogether the work under this award is important to understand both the mechanisms that permit an intact epithelium to change direction of migration to create the shape of a new organ, and also the mechanisms that maintain the integrity of the epithelium as the organ expands and changes shape.

 

In broader impacts from this award, two graduate students completed their PhD degrees, and a third made substantial progress towards completion. About 20 undergraduate students participated in this research, and two of these have entered MS degree programs at UNLV to pursue research careers in biology. The PI and graduate students in the lab worked with a cohort of biology graduate students to establish Science Cafe Las Vegas, a monthly gathering in which a Las Vegas scientist describes their research to a gathering of the public. This successful outreach event began in the end of 2015, with monthly events throughout the year.
